'''Veteran Feminists of America''' ('''VFA''') is a 501(c)(3) charitable organization for supporters and veterans of the Second Wave of the feminist revolution. Founded by [[Jacqueline Ceballos]] in 1992, Veteran Feminists of America regularly hosts reunions for [[second-wave feminist]]s and events honoring feminist leaders.
==VFA Mission statement==
The purpose of Veteran Feminists of America is to honor, record and preserve the history of the accomplishments of women active in the feminist movement, to educate the public on the importance of the changes brought about by the women's movement, to preserve the movement's history and to inspire future generations.
==History==
The Veteran Feminists of America was created with the goals of remembering and recording the faces and retrospectives of the hundreds of pioneers who launched the 1960s feminist movement, often called [[second-wave feminism]].
At first, VFA gatherings consisted of a time and place to meet and reminisce, followed by an awards dinner captured for posterity on video. Those videotapes are now archived at the [[Schlesinger Library]] at the [[Radcliffe Institute]] and the [[Sallie Bingham]] Center for Women's History and Culture at [[Duke University]]. Soon after their first reunion in 1992, [[Jacqueline Ceballos]] joined with Dorothy Senerchia and Mary Jean Tully to create the organization. [[Muriel Fox]] joined soon thereafter and has chaired the organization since 1994.
The original idea for a name, Veterans of Feminist Wars, was rejected because its acronym could be confused with that of the [[Veterans of Foreign Wars]] organization.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ceballos|first1=Jacqueline|title=A brief history by Jacqueline Ceballos, VFA Founder|url=http://www.vfa.us/History.htm|website=Veteran Feminists of America website|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref>
During its first decade, VFA mainly honored individuals and groups for their work in establishing national and local organizations, raising public awareness about feminist issues, and lobbying for women's rights. In time, VFA's events spread geographically and reached into new areas across the country.
In 1998, VFA Board member [[Barbara Love]], with help from her fellow VFA members, began compiling a directory of feminists, published in 2006 as ''Feminists Who Changed America: 1963-1975'' (University of Illinois Press). The book is a collection of 2,220 biographies of second-wave feminists who accomplished significant activist work.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Love|first1=Barbara|title=Feminists who Changed America|date=2006|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Urbana|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/feminists-who-changed-america-1963-1975/oclc/70174994|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref> It is also available as a searchable CD (www.fwca-cd.vetfems.org). ''Feminists Who Changed America'' — along with the videos from two decades of retrospective events — brings to life the history of feminism's [[Second-wave_feminism|second wave]]. It is meant to help to ensure that the achievements of the women's movement are not forgotten.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=DeLu|first1=Ardys|title=Review of Feminists Who Changed America.|journal=FemSpec|date=2007|volume=8|issue=1-2|page=122|url=http://www.femspec.org/8/abstracts.html#review|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref>
VFA has a new partnership with the New York Historical Society Museum & Library. Its newly created Center for Women's History will be the venue to showcase the artifacts and stories that document modern feminism.

{{about|the judge||Virginia Bell (actress)|and|Virginia Bell (baseball)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox judge | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] [[High Court of Australia|Justice]] | name = Virginia Bell | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=AUS|size=100|AC}} | image = | image_size = | office = [[List of Justices of the High Court of Australia|Justice of the High Court of Australia]] | nominator = [[Kevin Rudd]] | appointed = [[Quentin Bryce]] | term_start = 3 February 2009 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]] | occupation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1951|3|7|df=y}} | birth_place = | spouse = | children = | nationality = Australian }} '''Virginia Margaret Bell''' {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AC}} (born 7 March 1951) is the senior puisne Justice of the [[High Court of Australia]], the highest court in the [[Australian court hierarchy]]. She was sworn in on 3 February 2009.<ref name=agstatement>{{cite press release |publisher=Attorney General for Australia |date=15 December 2008 |author=McClelland, Robert |authorlink=Robert McClelland (Australian politician) |url=http://www.attorneygeneral.gov.au/www/ministers/robertmc.nsf/Page/MediaReleases_2008_FourthQuarter_15December2008-NewJusticeoftheHighCourt|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601035229/http://www.attorneygeneral.gov.au/www/ministers/robertmc.nsf/Page/MediaReleases_2008_FourthQuarter_15December2008-NewJusticeoftheHighCourt|archivedate=1 June 2009 |title=New Justice of the High Court |accessdate=15 December 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=15 December 2008 |agency=AAP |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/high-court-gets-fouth-woman/2008/12/15/1229189518021.html |title=High Court gets fourth woman |accessdate=15 December 2008 }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Bell was educated at [[SCEGGS Darlinghurst]] before attending the [[University of Sydney]], where she graduated in law in 1976.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/supreme_court/ll_sc.nsf/pages/SCO_speech_bell_250399 |title=Swearing In Ceremony of The Honourable Virginia Margaret Bell, SC as a Judge of the Supreme Court of NSW |publisher=Supreme Court of New South Wales |date=25 March 1999 |accessdate=25 February 2012 |author=Hole, Margaret }}</ref>
==Career== Bell was admitted as a solicitor of [[New South Wales]] in 1977. She was a solicitor at the [[Redfern Legal Centre]] from 1978–1984. Between 1982 and 1984, she was a member of the Board of Governors of the Law Foundation.<ref name=agstatement />
In 1984, Bell was [[Call to the Bar|called to the NSW bar]], joining Frederick Jordan [[Chambers (law)|Chambers]]. Bell was appointed a public defender in 1986, returning to private practice in late 1989. She was one of the counsel assisting the [[Wood Royal Commission|Wood]] [[Royal Commission]] into the New South Wales Police Service between 1994 and 1997. In November 1997, she was appointed Senior Counsel.<ref name=agstatement />
===Judicial career=== Bell was sworn in as a judge of the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales]] on 25 March 1999. She was appointed to the Court of Appeal of that court in early 2008, and was sworn out on 19 December 2008. She was sworn in as a judge of the High Court of Australia on 3 February 2009.<ref name=agstatement />
Bell was President of the Australasian Institute of Judicial Administration from 2007–2008. She was Chair of the University of Wollongong Law Faculty Advisory Committee from 2007-2008. From 1998-1999, she served as a part-time Commissioner of the NSW Law Reform Commission.<ref name=agstatement />
==Honours== On 26 January 2012, Bell was appointed a Companion of the [[Order of Australia]] for "eminent service to the judiciary and to the law through leadership in criminal law reform and public policy development, to judicial administration, and as an advocate for the economically and socially disadvantaged".<ref>{{cite news|title=Bell honoured for life of social justice|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/bell-honoured-for-life-of-social-justice-20120126-1qi51.html|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |agency=AAP |date=26 January 2012|accessdate=26 January 2012}}</ref>
==Personal life== Bell lives in inner Sydney with her female partner, a barrister.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/business/story/0,28124,24826156-17044,00.html |title=NSW Supreme Court farewells High Court appointee Virginia Bell |work=The Australian |date=20 December 2008 |accessdate= |author= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=John |last=Marsden |authorlink=John Marsden (lawyer) |title=I am what I am: my life and curious times |location=Camberwell, Victoria, Australia |publisher=Penguin |year=c. 2004 |page=71 |isbn=0-670-04052-5 |chapter=From Belanglo to Bangkok }}</ref> She has long been involved in the [[LGBT]] and human rights issues, participating in the first [[Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras|Mardi Gras]] LGBT rights rally in Sydney in 1978, which was broken up by police.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/2008/12/17/new-justice-a-78er/3381 |title=New justice a '78er |work=Sydney Star Observer |date=17 December 2008 |author= |accessdate= }}</ref> She is the first lesbian to serve on the High Court, and the second openly LGBT person after [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]], whom she replaced upon his retirement on 3 February 2009.
On her appointment, [[Australian Law Reform Commission]] president David Weisbrot opined that Bell will be a "progressive" jurist in the tradition of Michael Kirby.<ref>{{cite news |accessdate= |date=16 December 2008 |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/legal-affairs/bell-rings-in-new-era-for-high-court/story-e6frg97x-1111118328323 |title=Virginia Bell rings in new era for High Court |work=[[The Australian]] |author= }}</ref>
